pullRequest.body:
add `ContinuousMultilinearMap.apply`; use for `fderiv`, `iteratedFDeriv`, `SchwartzMap.iteratedPDeriv`

Defining `ContinuousMultilinearMap.apply` as a CLM (using existing proof of continuity) enables the proof that the application of a `ContinuousMultilinearMap` to a constant commutes with differentiation.

This closes a todo in `Mathlib/Analysis/Distribution/SchwartzSpace.lean`.

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:

- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body: I tweaked the PR title and labelling to match standard practices better. For some reason, "new feature" and "enhancement" were used in the early days of mathlib4, but not any more. Yes, that's a bit confusing, sorry.
Thanks very much for the explanations! I've removed the non-terminal simps, used ↦ notation, spelt out ContinuousLinearMap in the docs.

Welcome to mathlib! It's good to have more people; working together is more fun.

I took a look at your PR; looks pretty good already! I left a few comments about style; a more experience reviewer will have to comment about higher-level pieces. (I don't have approval powers.)

Welcome to mathlib! It's good to have more people; working together is more fun.

I took a look at your PR; looks pretty good already! I left a few comments about style; a more experience reviewer will have to comment about higher-level pieces. (I don't have approval powers.)
Thank you very much for the PR. I think being consistent within that file is the right call.
Thanks for the suggestions!
Another non-terminal simp. (See the next comment for what this means. Sorry for any confusion.)

In mathlib, we'd like to avoid a bare `simp` call in the middle of a proof. `simp only` is fine (you can use `simp?` to find such an invocation), as is using `simp` when it closes a goal.

In mathlib jargon, these are called "non-terminal simps". They are harder to maintain over time (and using `simp only` can be slightly faster). The [glossary](https://leanprover-community.github.io/glossary.html#non-terminal-simp) (beware, written for Lean 3!) explains a bit more why they're avoided.
Thanks! I didn't know that, and it makes sense
Do you want to write out "CLM", to remind the reader?

$\mapsto$ is slightly preferred over "=>". You can type the former as \map or \mapsto in VS Code.

Also applies in a couple of other places.
Updated
I'm wondering: should this (and the next three lemmas) use dot notation as well? (You might know better than me!)
I left this in the root namespace to match `fderivWithin_clm_apply`
*Personally*, I find `(u : (i : ι) → M i)` a bit clearer. Let's see what a more experienced reviewer says.
It is written like this in other files (namely `Analysis.NormedSpace.Multilinear.Basic`)

I did wonder whether it would be better to put this under `ContDiff.iteratedFDeriv_clm_apply_const_apply` (to enable use of dot notation) or `ContinuousLinearMap.iteratedFDeriv_apply_const_apply` (seems like a logical place but dot notation not possible as there is no `ContinuousLinearMap` argument). However, I left it in the root namespace to match `norm_iteratedFDeriv_clm_apply_const`.

```suggestion
    have h_deriv : DifferentiableOn 𝕜 (iteratedFDerivWithin 𝕜 i c s) s :=
```

```suggestion
    rw [fderivWithin_congr' (fun x hx ↦ ih hi.le hx) hx]
```

```suggestion
  exact iteratedFDerivWithin_clm_apply_const_apply uniqueDiffOn_univ hc.contDiffOn hi (mem_univ _)
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: fderiv of ContinuousMultilinearMap applied to const; use for SchwartzMap.iteratedPDeriv

nodes.body:
Welcome to mathlib! It's good to have more people; working together is more fun.

I took a look at your PR; looks pretty good already! I left a few comments about style; a more experience reviewer will have to comment about higher-level pieces. (I don't have approval powers.)

I tweaked the PR title and labelling to match standard practices better. For some reason, "new feature" and "enhancement" were used in the early days of mathlib4, but not any more. Yes, that's a bit confusing, sorry.
Thanks very much for the explanations! I've removed the non-terminal simps, used ↦ notation, spelt out ContinuousLinearMap in the docs.
Thank you very much for the PR. I think being consistent within that file is the right call.
Thanks for the suggestions!
